pageContext.claim: “I have the right to also take [the chairman of the Federal Reserve] and put him in a regular position and put somebody else in charge.”
pageContext.analysis: This isn't as cut and dry as Trump makes it sound. The updated 1977 law makes it hazy if a president can fire a chairman without “cause” like personal misconduct— a requirement that is spelled out as part of the original 1913 statute. Moreover, the Federal Reserve generally operates independently of politics and so, no president has attempted to remove a chairperson who has not been willing to resign.
